content.text: Step 1: Roll Accuracy
Every weapon has a single accuracy die — the die you roll to see if the attack lands. Bigger die = easier to hit. Smaller die = harder to hit but the weapon hits harder when it does.
Roll your weapon’s accuracy die and add your stat bonus.
Stat Value Bonus

Which stat? • Chrome → Melee weapon accuracy • Reflex → Ranged weapon accuracy (and melee weapons with the Finesse tag) • Interface → Rift pattern accuracy If the total (die + bonus) meets or exceeds the target’s Evasion, it’s a Hit.
Example: Chrome 6 (+3 bonus). You swing a Heavy Axe (d6 accuracy): roll a 3. Total: 3 + 3 = 6. Target Evasion 5? That’s a Hit.
Example: Reflex 8 (+4 bonus). You fire a Corp Rifle (d8 accuracy): roll a 2. Total: 2 + 4 = 6. Target Evasion 5? Hit.
Example: Reflex 4 (+2 bonus). You stab with a Combat Knife (d12 accuracy): roll a 1. Total: 1 + 2 = 3. Target Evasion 5? Miss.
Step 2: Apply Weapon Modifiers
Some weapons have conditional modifiers — bonuses or penalties based on the combat situation.

Examples: • Heavy Axe: +2 accuracy if you moved toward target this turn. • Sniper Rifle: +2 accuracy if you didn’t move. +2 if target didn’t move. -2 if you moved. -2 if target moved. • Scatter Gun: +2 accuracy at Adjacent/Close range. -2 at Medium+ range. • Spear: +2 accuracy vs targets who moved toward you this round.
Modifiers apply to the total accuracy roll. The total can’t go below 1.
Step 3: Roll Damage
On a Hit, roll the weapon’s damage dice. Each weapon has a fixed damage profile.
Example: Combat Knife hit → roll 1d6 damage. Example: Heavy Axe hit → roll 3d10 damage. Example: Rift Lance hit → roll 3d12 damage.
Step 4: Subtract Armor
The target’s Armor value is subtracted from each damage die individually. A damage die reduced below 1 deals 0 damage.
Example: Heavy Axe deals 3d10: roll 8, 3, 9. Target has Armor 3. Each die loses 3: 5, 0, 6 = 11 total damage.
Example: Combat Knife deals 1d6: roll 4. Target has Armor 3. 4 - 3 = 1 damage.
Example: Combat Knife deals 1d6: roll 2. Target has Armor 3. 2 - 3 = 0 damage. The blade bounces off.

This is why weapon choice matters against armored targets. Heavy weapons roll big damage dice that punch through armor. Light weapons roll small dice that get eaten by armor. Against armored enemies, you need big hits — not fast ones.
Step 5: Apply Damage
Subtract total remaining damage from the target’s HP. If HP reaches 0: See “Going Down“ below.
Attack Flow Summary

1. Roll accuracy die + stat bonus 2. Apply weapon conditional modifiers 3. Total ≥ Evasion = Hit 4. Hit → roll weapon damage dice 5. Subtract Armor from each damage die 6. Total remaining = damage dealt
Weapon AP Costs
Every weapon has an AP cost that determines how many times you can attack per turn and how much flexibility you have left over.
AP Cost Attacks/Turn Spare AP Tactical Profile
1 AP              5 attacks          0                 All-in flurry. No movement, no items. Pure aggression.
2 AP              2 attacks          1                 Two strikes, one spare for Move or Item. Balanced.
3 AP              1 attack           2                 One strike, full tactical flexibility (Move + Item).
4 AP              1 attack           1                 One devastating blow, one spare for Move or Item.

The trade-off is always damage vs. flexibility. A contractor with a Combat Knife (1 AP) can stab five times per turn but can’t move or use items. A contractor with a Longsword (3 AP) hits once but can move and use a healing stim on the same turn.
Critical Hits
A natural maximum on the accuracy die = Critical Hit.
Roll the accuracy die. If the die shows its highest face before adding bonuses, it’s a crit. A d6 showing 6. A d12 showing 12. The stat bonus doesn’t matter — only the natural roll.

Crit Rules: • Auto-hit — bypasses Evasion entirely • Double damage dice — roll twice as many damage dice as normal • Some weapons have special crit effects in addition to double damage Crit chance by accuracy die:
